OVERVIEW: The Ketchum series consists of very deep, well drained soils that formed in colluvium from limestone, quartzitic sandstone and related rock. Ketchum soils are on mountains and have slopes of 20 to 75 percent. Permeability is moderately rapid.  The average annual precipitation is about 20 inches, and the average annual temperature is about 38 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Xeric Haplocryepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Ketchum very gravelly loam - on 45 percent north facing slope at an elevation of 7,000 feet in timber.  When described on October 3, 1978, the soil was slightly moist throughout.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
0i--2 to 1 inches; undecomposed forest litter.
0e--1 to 0 inches; slightly decomposed forest litter.  (Combined thickness of the 0 horizons is 0 to 3 inches thick.)
A1--0 to 3 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very gravelly loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine irregular pores; 40 percent gravel and 5 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 6.8); abrupt wavy boundary.  (3 to 8 inches thick.)
A2--3 to 11 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) very gravelly fine sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak fine to medium granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine irregular pores; 35 percent gravel and 10 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 6.8); abrupt wavy boundary.  (6 to 9 inches thick)
Bw1--11 to 32 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) very gravelly fine sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; common very fine tubular pores; 45 percent gravel and 10 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 7.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (7 to 21 inches thick.)
Bw2--32 to 42 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3), very gravelly sandy loam; brown (10YR 5/3) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine tubular pores; 40 percent gravel and 10 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 7.0) clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 16 inches thick.)
BC--42 to 48 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4), very gravelly sandy loam; dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine tubular pores; 50 percent gravel and 5 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.  (6 to 32 inches thick.)
C--48 to 61 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) extremely gravelly coarse sandy loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; single grain; loose; many very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; 75 percent gravel and 10 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 7.0).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Blaine County, Idaho about 4 miles east and 3 miles north of Hailey; 1,400 feet south and 100 feet west of the northeast corner of sec. 19, T.3 N., R.19 E.  Latitude 43 degrees, 34 minutes, and 45 seconds north; Longitude 114 degrees, 13 minutes, and 46 seconds west.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Depth to quartzitic sandstone - more than 60 inches Average annual soil temperature - 38 to 42 degrees F. Average summer soil temperature - 54 to 59 degrees F. without an O horizon Percent clay, particle-size control section - 10 to 20 percent Base saturation by ammonium acetate - 60 to 75 percent in some subhorizon within a depth of 75 cm
A horizon Value, dry - 4 through 6 Value, moist - 2 through 4 Chroma, moist or dry - 2 or 3 Reaction - moderately acid to neutral
Bw horizon Hue 2.5Y or 10YR Value, dry - 6 or 7 Value, moist - 4 or 5 Chroma, moist or dry - 2 through 4 Texture - GRV-L, GRV-SL, or GRV-FSL Rock fragments - 35 to 60 percent Reaction - slightly acid or neutral
BC horizon Hue - 2.5Y or 10YR Texture - GRV-SL, GRV-FSL, or GRV-L Rock fragments - 35 to 60 percent Reaction - slightly acid or neutral
C horizon Color value, dry - 6 or 7 Value, moist - 4 or 5 Chroma, moist or dry - 2 or 3 Texture - GRX-FSL or GRX-COSL Rock fragments - 60 to 80 percent Reaction - slightly acid to slightly alkaline

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Longhike (T) and Muiral series. Longhike soils are 30 to 40 inches to a paralithic contact. Muiral soils are moderately deep to bedrock.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Ketchum soils are on north and east-facing mountains.  Slopes range from 20 to 75 percent.  Elevation ranges from 6,000 to 8,900 feet.  The soil formed in colluvium from limestone, quartzitic sandstone and related rock.  The average annual precipitation is 18 to 24 inches, most of which falls as snow and early spring rains. The average annual air temperature is about 36 to 40 degrees F.  The frost-free season is less than 60 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Dollarhide, Milligan, Povey, and Vitale soils.  Dollarhide soils have bedrock at less than 20 inches.  Milligan, Povey, and Vitale soils have mollic epipedons. Milligan and Vitale soils are on south and west-facing slopes. Dollarhide soils are on ridgetops and Povey soils are on the same landscape as Ketchum soils.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; rapid to very rapid runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Mainly used for range and timber.  Vegetation is Douglas-fir with an understory of mountain snowberry, pine reedgrass, elk sedge and ninebark.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  South-central Idaho.  This series is inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:   Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - occurs from the soil surface to 11 inches (A1 and A2 hrozions)
Cambic horizon - occurs from 11 to 42 inches (Bw1 and Bw2 horizons).
Xeric soil moisture regime.
Particle-size control section - zone from 10 to 40 inches (part of the A2, the Bw1 and part of the Bw2 horizons)
The 3/2008 description reflects a change in classification from Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Xeric Eutrocryepts to Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Xeric Haplocryepts due to revision of the cryepts great groups and subgroups. The competing series section was not updated and should be reviewed after all the cryepts have been re-classified.
